segments.text: Okay, this is Ron Shorn in Boulder, Colorado, interviewing Rita F. Beebe on October 21st, 1993.
Rita, for the record, could you give your full name?
Rita Faye Jenkins Beebe.
Okay, and when and where were you born?
In Pritchett, Colorado, October 10th, 1936.
How do you spell Pritchett?
T-R-I-T-C-H-E-T-T but I don't believe it exists anymore.
Where did you get interested in astronomy at the beginning?
I had a strange childhood.
I grew up near Boulder, Colorado.
My father was 54 years old when I was born.
He was a cow puncher in his younger days and had settled into ranching and farming by the time I came along.
As a cowpuncher, he spent a considerable number of winters with remittance men in line shacks.
And these people were people who were very well-schooled dropouts from Eastern culture in those days.
My father's interest, having had only a third-grade education,
was in nature and the knowledge he had accumulated was that of a naturalist in the old fashioned sense.
So I grew up believing everybody knew about constellations and everybody asked questions about stars.
I had mechanical tendencies and was frequently accused of stealing my father's tools when he lost them and that sort of thing and having no brothers to compete with.
I was allowed to develop my interests

I developed sort of a two-pronged interest in the fact that I also wanted to be an artist, and I actually spent the first two years of my college days majoring in art before I turned back to the physical sciences.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
I went to art school at Washburn University in Topeka, Kansas, and the Kansas City Art Institute, and then returned to Colorado University.
Why did you go to Kansas?
Fellowships.
All right, so then you went back after you left art school and went to?
Colorado University.
Okay, in Boulder.
Yes.
And what did you major in there?
Chemistry.
Chemistry.
Why chemistry?
Because at that time I was going to be a veterinarian, and I couldn't put the financial package together for that.
So then I moved into teaching junior high school, junior high school,
We went into an extensive curriculum development, and I moved into teaching earth science, and after three years of that, then I came back to graduate school.
Okay, when did you get your bachelor's degree?
Fifty-nine.
Okay, and when did you enter graduate school?
In 62, I guess?
Yeah.
Where did you go to grad school?
Indiana University.
Why did you pick Indiana?
Previous to Indiana University, I went back to the University of Idaho for two years to upgrade my physics and mathematics.
And then did a survey of graduate schools.
And I got married in 59.
So that parallel to my development, my husband was doing the same thing.
So we were going to enter graduate school together.
And we picked Indiana because they gave us a double financial package that we needed.
How long did you stay at Indiana as a grad student?
When did you get out?
Sixty-nine.
Sixty-nine.
What was your doctoral dissertation and who was your advisor?
The work was on R. Cygnus, a red giant star with anomalous heavy metal abundance.
My thesis advisor was Benjamin Franklin Peary.
OK, so you got your PhD in when?
October of 69.
I covered that.
So where did you go after that?
When did your husband get his degree?
He got his in September of 69.
He got a position at New Mexico State University as an assistant professor in astronomy.
I had worked as a graduate student at Los Alamos.
And at that time, there were not two jobs available.
But I was well enough established at Los Alamos that I could continue to consult part time.
And we were working on molecular opacities calculations.
And that was quite compatible.
The New Mexico State University gave me office space and computer access free of charge.
So it was quite a comfortable arrangement.
Okay, and what were you working on there?
I was interacting with the Los Alamos group, working on opacities.
Then in January of that year, I began to work with Brad Smith.
Okay, how did that come about?
Elmer Rees had developed quite a few measurements of drift rates of clouds in the atmosphere of Jupiter.
He had lost his collaborator, Gordon Solberg, to controversial political issues and needed some assistance.
So I started working just part time on the Los Alamos situation and part time for Brad Smith to help Elmer Reese with that interpretation.
OK. How long did that happen?
I mean, how long did you stay in that position doing that kind of work?
After about a year, we wrote new proposals and I became fully funded in the study of Jupiter's atmosphere and worked as a research associate until 1974.
Okay.
And what did you do research on until 1974?
Jupiter and Venus ground-based data.
Okay.
What kind of data?
Photographic.
Okay.
What happened in 1974?
1974, Brad Smith left New Mexico State, moved to the University of Arizona.
And I was selected to replace him as a tender track assistant professor of astronomy.
And what's happened to your career since then?
We continued to study Jupiter.
And in 1977, I joined the Voyager team
to assist in the targeting of the imaging and continue to work on that project.
Since Voyager wound down, what have your interests been?
I moved over to Hubble Space Telescope.
I've been principal investigator on teams that are utilizing the WIFPIC
planetary camera mode and the faint object spectrograph to do correlative studies of changes in wind fields, cloud wave formation, and spectroscopic data.
When you first got into planetary astronomy, did you feel that real, quote, unquote, astronomy was considered at second rate?
I have been known to say that I haven't experienced sexual discrimination.
I've experienced racial discrimination.
Yes, there has been a general tendency to do that.
I consider it a lack of ego on their part.
I think they feel grossly challenged because when we attempt to do our work, we have higher spatial resolution.
We have more information.
Our physical interpretations are frequently more sophisticated than theirs.
Do you think planetary astronomy is a little more respected now than it was when you first got into the game?
Yes, I think so.
What was planetary astronomy like when you first got into it?
I mean, size, attitudes, the kind of people that were in it as compared to now?
Actually, by the time I really started participating in activities outside of New Mexico State, there was a fair amount of excitement about it.
I remember the second Division of Planetary Sciences meeting was in Tallahassee.
I found that meeting extremely exciting.
I found another thing about it rather strange in the sense that I encountered strange discrimination.
I was not allowed to buy my own drinks in that state at that time as a female, although I was at that point in time becoming recognized as a working scientist.
The culture hadn't caught up with it yet, definitely.
What's the best piece of work you've done?
The coordination, the targeting, and the interpretation of Voyager 1 Jupiter encounter.
The really satisfying thing about that encounter was, yes, we did know a lot about these clouds, and yes, we did know how to find them.
And much of the work that we had done before that, that people felt might be over-interpreting the limited ground-based resolution, then became accepted.
So that in retrospect, we could go backward and put even more physical constraints on the atmosphere than the Voyager data itself allowed.
Did anything about the Voyager information about Jupiter surprise you?
I hadn't done a lot of consideration about the magnetic field or the surface conditions of the satellites before we arrived.
Those were surprising to me, and part of it was that I hadn't pushed as hard as I probably should have in those areas.
the atmospheric results, I would say satisfied me.
That was wonderful to see that much of what we thought was true really was and to just gain higher and higher resolution.
Voyager 1 was wonderful because we had almost 90 days of that trip in the sense that every day I went in I was seeing a little higher resolution, a little more
of the understanding, so it really was a wonderful thing.
I'll never live through another trip like that.
Have you had any dead ends or fiascos or things that you wish you wouldn't have gotten involved with?
I wish I had the time back that I have spent trying to figure out what triggers disturbances in Jupiter's atmosphere.
I've looked at almost every combination of satellites, tides, all sorts of things, and every one of them is just pulled up as a dead end.
If I had that time back, I could probably do some very nice stuff with it.
Where was your first encounter with National Aeronautics and Space Administration?
When did they first give you money or put you on a board or something?
Seventy-four.
And that was?
That was a grant, yes.
Okay.
All right, and you've had frequent contact with NASA since then.
Quite so.
How do you think they handle the management of planetary science in general?
My feeling is that the people who have been managing my contracts are excellent.
It's the structure above that.
And the financial structures have become very complicated.

Gerard de Bacallure was very strong in saying that he was really annoyed at the fact that NASA would get some pretty pictures out of a probe and then not support the follow-on research, just cut things off.
Did you find that was true?
I have aggressively worked to keep M.O.
and D.A.
financed over the years, and yes, it's a constant problem, and it's a real problem simply because it is the one thing that can be delayed.
So that it's sitting there always vulnerable for any sort of a taxation or a budget cut
It's the one that's sticking out in the wind ready to be clipped off.
And that's not just NASA.
That happens everywhere, in business and everywhere.
You can always delay the fine analysis of a project so that it's just an ongoing problem.
People who are involved in it will continually have to fight.
Where do you think
Planetary astronomy today would be if it wasn't for the money that NASA put into it in the last 30 years.
Well, I suppose it would still be back in the realm of astrology, quite frankly.
Because there really was a huge resistance to letting it grow academically.
And that came not only from the classical astronomers, but it also came from the classical physicists.
because it was their territory that would be encroached in academia.
And without NASA, this area would have been expected to exist in academia.
There were several big funding crunches in NASA history.
One was in 73, one was in 81, and it looks like we're getting another one now.
And things have been tight for a number of years.
When you get an intelligent student or intelligent students who say, gee, I want to go into grad school and be a planetary astronomer, what do you tell them now?
Well, I have a discussion with them about the potential, but my own attitude, which I convey to them, is that if they are good enough, they will probably be able to survive in it.
and quite frankly, if they wanted to become an architect, or any of the other applied physical sciences where your real survival is your own creativity, they'll have the same kind of tough time.
Now, if they're second rate, I will do my best to encourage them to decide that they really would rather do something else.
There's been some talk lately of turning NASA into the national...
Aeronautics Administration giving space research to the Air Force, who already does a lot.
And of course, before there was an NSA, the Air Force poured a lot of money into planetary astronomy and related topics.
If that happened, would you mind working for the Air Force?
No.
We're at a division for... Don't forget I've already worked for Los Alamos.
I like the idea that there are a few intelligent people working for the agencies who develop our ability to go to war.
I don't want that left to people who are warriors by nature.
We're at the Division for Planetary Sciences of the American Astronomical Society meeting.
25 years ago, 26 years ago, there was no special organization for planetary astronomy.
And in fact, there was no special journal for planetary astronomy.
And now there's Icarus and also the Journal for Geophysical Research-Planet.
Do you think that this specialization has been good, bad, indifferent, inevitable?
What's your opinion?
I think the specialization has been good.
I think the fact that it's been recognized as an area that should have been pursued and developed has changed the basic attitude of ordinary people.
When you walk into an elementary classroom or a group of freshman students, their concept of their surroundings has been grossly modified by the space program.
and it's been modified in a constructive way in the sense that they have been able to see more than one planet.

They have seen things that are as spectacular as science fiction can deliver to them, and they have been introduced to the concept of cause and effect in a very graphical way that has led them not only to know that this sort of
logic exists, but to expect it, to expect there to be an explanation of the spectacular.
Since you've done both, you're an appropriate person to ask, do you ever get annoyed when some popular book or TV show claims that spacecraft discovered everything we know about the solar system?
It doesn't bother me that much.
Because quite honestly, spacecraft has brought it to the attention of the public.
I certainly attempt to correct that over time.
Do you think that planetary astronomy is a part of astronomy?
Definitely.
Just, there's one other thing I don't know.
Astronomy is a part of NASA.
The traditional astronomy is, by a very large part, now funded by NASA.
The breakdown between NSF and NASA is shocking to me.
I mean, the entire field of astronomy is now dependent, for most of its support, from NASA.
This came with the development of the great observatory projects and that sort of thing.
Like the Hubble Space Telescope.
The shift is huge.
NSF is supporting very little of the whole astronomical academic community at this point.
Do you think that's good or bad?
I think it's bad.
I think we've slid into a situation.
Any time you have federal funding for projects that are pushing technology,
the number of people in the field will expand to the limit that those projects can accept.
And we've had this major expansion in all of the areas, and it can't continue to expand.
The fact that we're suffering a budget crunch is caused by many different aspects, and one is 25 years of expansion of these fields.
Let me ask you, how old do you consider planetary astronomy to be?
Because there's two schools of thought.
One says it didn't really begin until Galileo had the sky in the telescope.
And others would say, well, it started back when the first Swiss lake dweller looked at the sky and saw that Venus was this bright thing in the sky after sunset.
What's your opinion?
Actually, I think
Planetary science as such really started in the 50s.
Before that, it was a part of our natural science lore.
And in the 1950s, people began to understand spectroscopy enough to realize that they could do some very significant remote sensing.
They began to look for general physical explanations.
They began to do detailed studies.
A classical one is Kuiper's study of trying to understand the red spot.
A beautiful study in the sense that
that, again, here was the real realization that we could expand ourselves, stretch ourselves, and really push the concept of cause and effect.
And to me, that was the point that the field that we call planetary science, where we're really relating
other planets to the Earth instead of saying these are wonderful things with some mystic properties associated with them.
We're saying these are different cases of the same thing we have here.
To me, that's when planetary science, as I see planetary science, began.
Of all the discoveries that have come about in the last 30 years, what
Was it really most astounding to you, the one that you'd say, I never would have thought of that, or I never would have believed that?
The volcanoes on Mars.
There was just something wonderful about them.
I was ready to accept that Mars had never had plate tectonics.
But it had never occurred to me that instead of plate tectonics, you would have activity that just sat there and piled up.
That concept is just neat.
Do you think planetary astronomers and planetary scientists have done a good job in selling themselves, or as good a job as they could have, to the public and to the Congress?
I think they've done an excellent job of selling themselves to the public.
I travel a lot.
I'm on a lot of committees.
And if I'm on a plane and somebody opens a conversation that I really don't want to pursue, asking me what I do, I tell them I'm an astrophysicist and that's the end of that conversation.
I tell them I work in planetary science and the conversation will last until the plane lands.
I think that's a good measure of the fact we've done it.
Selling ourselves to Congress.
That's another question.
I think we've probably done a better job of that than most of the other physical sciences.
What effect, if any, do you think on the public interest and funding is the fact that we found no trace whatsoever of light anywhere in the solar system except Earth, and in particular not on Mars?

i think that stimulated our funding uh during the period of time that we were on our survey of the solar system mode we're now past that i think it may actually curtail our funding now because i think what we have done with that is that we have made people more aware that this is all we got and we better save it so i think in the long run our efforts have
actually done a better job of selling the need to really understand this planet as a unit, so that we probably enhanced the area we now refer to as Earth Sciences.
How did planetary studies get started at New Mexico State?
In the 50s, Clyde W. Tombaugh, who had moved to White Sands,
At White Sands, he set up tracking cameras for studying the ballistic trajectories of various test rockets and that sort of thing.
And in the mid-'50s, he decided that he wanted to free himself up from some of the details that he
was forced to accept if he continued to live at the White Sands Proving Grounds.
So he requested the right from the military to move his contracts to New Mexico State University, which was a small university.
Its research was centered in the central office, which would give him first class service.
So he moved to New Mexico State.
Among the people that he had acquired to work with him at White Sands was Bradford Smith.

And after they moved to New Mexico State, the two of them worked as a team to develop ground-based monitoring of basically Mars when they first started, with an eye toward understanding the seasonal aspects for space exploration.
And then later they acquired the services of Elmer Rees, a gifted amateur astronomer
all of the right attributes to be an outstanding observational scientist where did they get the money to do this at first it was air force and then they moved to nasa for me okay and then uh
Were you the next hire that came along?
No.
Clyde had a faculty slot in Earth Sciences.
And he expanded his contracts to the point that he had an observing team, which I think he had as many as five observers on staff at a time.
I was the first PhD to join his staff.
And Clyde was still the PI of the group when I joined, although he retired soon after that, and Brad Smith became the PI.
Now, what happened then?
I mean, what department were you in?
I was in earth science.
And in 1969, the astronomy separated from earth science and became an individual department.
William Reitmeier was the department head.
And by the time I arrived, there were three stellar galactic type astronomers.
And Herb Beebe was the theoretician.
He was actually a solar astronomer.
So the fact that the Sacramento Peak Observatory was there was extremely attractive to him, because he could do his observing there and then do his modeling at the university.
Well, what's happened since then?
I mean, what's happened to the astronomy department?
Has it grown much?
Over the years, we attempted several times to set up an effective consortium to build a large telescope.
And we have managed to do that.
University of Chicago, Princeton University, University of Washington and Washington State and New Mexico State have developed a consortium.
Recently, Johns Hopkins and
the Institute of Advanced Studies at Princeton have come in.
We have a three and a half meter
honeycomb-type Naismith-focused telescope that will be coming online within the next six months.
It's now waiting for its secondary.
Everything else is in position and tested.
And it will be located, it is located at?
Apache Peak, which is 100 miles from the campus on paved, maintained roads.
And we have remote observing capabilities.
How many faculty do you have now in the astronomy department?
We have two planetary astronomers that are on tenure track.
Myself is tenured, and we have a junior person who has been with us for a year and a half.
That's Mark Marley.
Jack Burns is our current department head, and he is a radio astronomer, interacts considerably with the VLA.
Rene Walterbos, galactic astronomy.
Walt Sanders and Kurt Anderson, both stellar population galactic structure types.
Bernie McNamara, variable stars, catastrophic variable stars.
That's the tenure track group.
We have Bill Weber, retired from New Hampshire, high energy astrophysics.
He's a university professor.
Nick Devereaux, a young NASA investigator.
Galactic astronomy.
Andre Klippen, the Tombaugh Fellow.
We have developed an endowment in honor of Clyde Tombaugh.
And Andre, a Soviet cosmologist, is our first fellow.
Do you planetary types talk with the other astronomers much?
Oh, yes, yes.
As a matter of fact, the major thrust that's developing in galactic astronomy at New Mexico State is hydrodynamics.
Yes, because hydrodynamics is quite well developed in planetary astronomy.
Mark Marley is quite interested in energy balance in the upper atmosphere, and so am I.
So the overlaps with the
Most newly acquired galactic people are open, friendly, and very collaborative.
Some of the older traditional astronomers are still sitting off in their stuffy corners, but they're literally isolated from both sides now.
Well, of course, you have the advantage that you don't just have a snapshot, which is all you get.
You can actually see things changing on Jupiter, which makes it a little more tricky to make predictions.
Actually, our radio astronomers can see things changing, too.
supersonic jets change with time, too.
So the concepts of modeling and displaying time changes and that sort of thing really do overlap.
That brings me to another point, which is that radio astronomy, which is what I started out in, was really founded not by astronomers but by engineers.
And in the
Well, the 40s and the 50s.
It had a hard time getting started in this country because the astronomers at the time had about the same attitude towards the dirty engineering work as they did towards looking at the planets.
And radio astronomy has never had a bias, as far as I know, against planetary astronomy.
How do you get along with the radio astronomers now?
because it's a new generation of people.
The old timers are mostly gone.
But I wanted your opinion on that.
And many of the numerics are so parallel.
Around the turn of this century, planetary astronomy was still a significant part of astronomy.
Henry Norris Russell did papers on the atmosphere of Venus and so forth.
But by the end of World War I, it was basically dead.
I mean, there were a few people still working, but it was basically dead.
Who or what killed it, in your opinion?
probably the lack of infrared observations coming along at the right time we really had a dearth of new observational input
and most of the interesting spectral features are in the infrared, unfortunately.
The development of large telescopes that did not enhance our spatial resolution sort of made the planets not that desirable.
And then the fact that we weren't able to use those large light buckets to reach into another frequency domain and give us some more constraints is probably what really put it down.
Gerard de Bacalaur has a...
vehement two-word answer to that question.
Percival Law.
Do you think that would have an effect?
No, I don't.
I think the fact that you see too many bubbles of air, Earth's air, in a big telescope had the biggest effect because much of the money was being recruited to support the big telescopes.
And we really weren't competitive on them.
really couldn't pull new, exciting information out.
If the spatial resolution had been directly proportional to the diameter of the telescope, Percival Lowell couldn't have touched us.
The idea of what we would have seen on Mars would have just been so intriguing that...
I wanted to ask your...
This is a detail that may not get in the book, but I want your opinion.

You know, now with CCDs, you can beat the scene and take pictures of, in particular, Mars, that look like the sort of stuff that those of us who have looked at Mars through telescopes will occasionally see but could never photograph or even draw.
Were you relieved to see that those images actually were just like what you'd been seeing in the past?
Sure.
The idea of being able to record and then go back and analyze is always exciting.
Sure, you believe what you see.
After you understand how the human eye interprets things, you know that those details are there.
But you can't remember them.
You can't intercompare them.
The classical example of this is Elmer Rees, who had observed an excellent observer.

And when he was finally allowed to have the A Mountain, the Tortugas Mountain, photographic record, so he could go back and see what a south equatorial belt storm looked like in 71 and compare it to 75, it was like, you know, manna from heaven to him.
One thing that's been a petty annoyance of mine, and I wonder if it's been of yours,
is that the pictures they release of Mars and the whole disk from various spacecraft
don't look like it looks when you look directly at it.
They fiddle around with the data.
Does that kind of tick you off?
Yes, it kind of ticks me off.
And there's a fair amount of it going on now in ground base, too.
High pass filtering, edge finders being used to really enhance the edge structures, total destruction of the photometry.

One of the things that bothers me a little bit about the Voyager representation of Jupiter is the fact that in order to get high contrast images into the American living room, we grossly enhance the color.
And we have left the public with the concept of the appearance of these cloud decks.
It's wrong.
Lately, there's been a fair amount of effort to make planetary science practical, and there's certainly been a lot of publicity about killer asteroids and comets, the ozone layer, global warming.
Do you think that's gone too far, or do you think it's just about right, or not enough?
I think it's gone too far.
I don't think that that is the real application of planetary science.
I think that...
The real application of planetary science in the field of education is the idea of physical processes.
More than one laboratory to understand what has gone on over time, developing the general understanding of time dependence on Earth.
We could do real structures there.
Killer asteroids is...
I don't think planetary people invented that.
I think SDI people invented that, looking for a home.
And I think that's appalling.
I think it's misleading.
I think it's asking the American public to pay attention to something that is not as likely to happen as some of the other pending catastrophes that we should be expending resources on.
What do you think is going to happen?
Well, first of all, do you think planetary astronomy is kind of mined out now or not?
No, I don't think so.
I think that... Well, I talk to elementary students a lot.
Elementary students are ready to go to the moon, even if they have to live in a hole.
As long as I will let them have television, they would love to go to the moon.
The concept of a 14-day...
day is fascinating to them.
Sixth graders would like to take pregnant women to the moon so they can watch the children grow up under low G. It's this concept of just a little different environment.
I think we've still got a lot of very interesting

stimulating this same toward really improving education really improving critical ability do you think there will be money to support planetary strategy no I think we're headed toward period time where support really is going to decrease and then I think that maybe

20 years from now we'll we'll see an increase in interest in it again and it'll come back um i forgot to ask you one thing about the situation in new mexico state now it was a small college 30 years ago what was how would you characterize the attitude of the higher-ups there you know whatever they are the regents or the deans or the presidents or chancellors towards having um
you know, a real research group, and in particular astronomy.
Were they amazed that there was such a subject?
No, not at all, because the proper people of Pasadena chased the Caltech people out of Arroyo Sepe to the White Sands Proving Ground, so that the development of
The space program is very closely associated with New Mexico in the minds of most of the people there.
The first satellite that was to go into Earth orbit that didn't get off the launch pad carried a communications package that had been built at New Mexico State.
New Mexico State has been very strong in telemetry and communications, so that we came in two
this area from the technological side, and the physical science was second to develop there, but it was natural that it did develop there.
New Mexico State has a very large involvement in military funding.
They entrap, process, and deliver a large portion of the data that's acquired at the White Sands Missile Range.
You're undoubtedly aware of the fact that astronomy is, I guess, without astronomy in general and planetary astronomy in particular, is the most popular science with the general public.
How come?
Well, it's not quite as mundane as Earth-based science.
There's still a little bit of the fascination of science fiction in it.
But at the same time, because people have been living on a planet, they've got all the fundamental basis for understanding it.
So it's something that's familiar but mind-stretching at the same time.
It's been my opinion that astronomy is the best carrot that you can use as a teacher to get people to learn science.
Do you agree?
No.
and elementary students like bugs just as well when does that start to change about the sixth grade any idea why i guess they get tired of bugs when you've done grasshoppers too how far can you go
